verses.text: Great is the Lord and most worthy of praise, in the city of our God, on His holy mountain.
verses.comment: The city of God on His holy mountain refers to Jerusalem and emphasizes the centrality of worship in a specific place established by God. See similarities in Ps. 87:1-3. This foreshadows the gathering of God's people in His chosen assembly, a mystery fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: Beautiful in elevation, the joy of the whole earth, Mount Zion, in the far north, the city of the Great King.
verses.comment: Mount Zion as 'the city of the Great King' is echoed in Jesus' words in Matt. 5:35. The spiritual significance points beyond earthly location to the role of God's people as His visible presence among the nations.

verses.text: God is in her citadels; He has made Himself known as a fortress.
verses.comment: God is truly present in His city, a theme developed further in Ps. 132:13-14. Consider both the visible and spiritual aspects of God’s dwelling among His people.

verses.text: For behold, the kings assembled; they advanced together.
verses.comment: Many nations join together against God’s city, recalling Ps. 2:2 where rulers plot in vain. This prefigures opposition to God's chosen assembly throughout salvation history.

verses.text: As soon as they saw it, they were astounded; they were terrified and fled.
verses.comment: God’s presence brings fear to His enemies, recalling how God defended His people in Exodus. Christ’s victory over the powers of evil brings similar awe.

verses.text: Trembling seized them there, anguish like that of a woman in labor.
verses.comment: The sudden defeat of God’s enemies is likened to birth pains (see Mark 13:8), a recurring image of God’s final judgment but also of the coming of His kingdom.

verses.text: With the east wind You shatter the ships of Tarshish.
verses.comment: God’s judgment is mighty and sudden, destroying the greatest powers. Ships of Tarshish signify wealth and strength made nothing before God.

verses.text: As we have heard, so have we seen in the city of the Lord of hosts, in the city of our God; God will establish her forever. Selah.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness to establish His city endures forever. The reference anticipates the fullness of God’s assembly as described in Revelation 21, the new Jerusalem (see also Heb. 12:22).

verses.text: Within Your temple, O God, we meditate on Your steadfast love.
verses.comment: Worship at God’s temple is central to encountering His love. The continual meditation and sacrificial worship point to the necessity of an enduring and visible form of worship.

verses.text: As Your name, O God, so is Your praise to the ends of the earth; Your right hand is full of righteousness.
verses.comment: God’s praise and righteousness are meant for all nations. This hints at God’s plan for the unity of all peoples under His reign, brought to completion in Christ.

verses.text: Let Mount Zion be glad, let the daughters of Judah rejoice because of Your judgments.
verses.comment: The joy of God’s people flows from the justice of His rule. The term 'daughters of Judah' includes outlying towns, emphasizing the universality and inclusiveness of His kingdom.

verses.text: Walk about Zion, go around her, count her towers,
verses.comment: The invitation to meditate upon the city’s strength suggests both literal security and the spiritual reality of God’s enduring dwelling with His people.

verses.text: notice her ramparts, go through her citadels, so that you may tell the next generation
verses.comment: Passing on the works of God from generation to generation is a recurring theme (see Ps. 78:4), reinforcing the duty to preserve the faith and instruction through tradition.

verses.text: that this is God, our God forever and ever. He will guide us forever.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness extends to all ages. He guides His people eternally, promising not only earthly security but a relationship that is everlasting, culminating in His presence with them forever (Rev. 21:3).
